protocols.name: Time-Restricted Eating
protocols.description: Limiting daily food intake to a specific time window, typically 8-10 hours
protocols.implementation: Start with a 12-hour eating window (e.g., 8am to 8pm) and gradually reduce to 8-10 hours (e.g., 10am to 6pm).
protocols.evidence: Multiple studies show improvements in glucose metabolism and inflammatory markers with 8-10 hour eating windows.
protocols.cautions: May not be suitable for pregnant women, those with eating disorders, or those with certain medical conditions. Consult a healthcare provider.
resources: The Circadian Code by Dr. Satchin Panda

protocols.name: Progressive Resistance Training
protocols.description: Regular strength training to build and maintain muscle mass
protocols.implementation: Start with 2-3 sessions per week of full-body resistance training. Focus on compound movements (squats, deadlifts, push-ups, rows) and gradually increase weight/resistance.
protocols.evidence: Resistance training improves insulin sensitivity and increases hormonal production, particularly testosterone.
protocols.cautions: Start with proper form and lighter weights. Consider working with a trainer initially. Those with joint issues should modify exercises accordingly.

protocols.name: Vitamin D Supplementation
protocols.implementation: Typical supplementation is 1,000-5,000 IU daily with a meal containing fat. Dosage should be based on current blood levels.
protocols.evidence: Vitamin D deficiency is associated with increased all-cause mortality and accelerated aging.
protocols.cautions: Very high doses can lead to toxicity. Regular blood testing is recommended when supplementing. Consult a healthcare provider for personalized dosing.
resources: The Vitamin D Solution by Dr. Michael Holick

protocols.name: Cold Exposure Therapy
protocols.description: Regular exposure to cold temperatures through cold showers, ice baths, or outdoor activities in cold weather
protocols.implementation: Start with 30 seconds of cold water at the end of a shower, gradually building to 5 minutes. Alternative: ice baths starting at 2 minutes and building to 10-15 minutes at 50-60°F.
protocols.evidence: Cold exposure activates brown adipose tissue and can increase mitochondrial efficiency. Some evidence suggests hormetic benefits for inflammation markers.
protocols.cautions: Not recommended for those with cardiovascular conditions, Raynaud's syndrome, or cold urticaria. Start gradually to avoid shock.
resources: The Wim Hof Method by Wim Hof

protocols.name: Sleep Optimization
protocols.description: Improving sleep quality and duration through behavioral changes and environment optimization
protocols.implementation: Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep. Establish a consistent sleep schedule, create a dark, cool sleeping environment (65-68°F), avoid screens 1-2 hours before bed, and limit caffeine after noon.
protocols.evidence: Poor sleep directly impacts glucose metabolism, increases inflammation, and disrupts hormone production.
protocols.cautions: If sleep problems persist despite interventions, consider consulting a sleep specialist to rule out sleep disorders.
resources: Why We Sleep by Matthew Walker

protocols.name: Regular Meditation Practice
protocols.implementation: Start with 5 minutes of daily guided meditation using an app like Headspace, Calm, or Waking Up. Gradually increase to 20 minutes daily.
protocols.evidence: Regular meditation has been shown to reduce inflammatory markers and may help maintain telomere length.
protocols.cautions: None significant. If anxiety increases during meditation, try guided or walking meditation alternatives.
resources: Altered Traits by Daniel Goleman and Richard Davidson

protocols.name: B Vitamin Complex
protocols.description: Supplementation with B vitamins, particularly B6, B9 (folate), and B12
protocols.implementation: Take a high-quality B complex daily, preferably with active forms (methylfolate, methylcobalamin, P5P). Alternatively, specific B6 (50mg), folate (400-800mcg), and B12 (500-1000mcg) supplements.
protocols.evidence: B vitamins are critical for proper homocysteine metabolism. Deficiencies directly lead to elevated homocysteine levels.
protocols.cautions: Some individuals with MTHFR gene mutations may need specific forms of folate. Very high dose B6 (>200mg daily) can cause neuropathy over time.
resources: The Homocysteine Revolution by Kilmer McCully
